results.title: How the myth was made
results.creator_credit: George C. Stoney, James B. Brown and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description: Reconstructs the filming of Robert Flaherty’s film “Man of Aran”. Includes interviews with participants in the original project and raises questions about some scenes in the original film, which were of long discontinued activities re-enacted for the 1934 film. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: How the motor car works
results.brief_description: This series explains the mechanics of the motor car, a machine that has changed the world profoundly, influencing economic and social development. Areas covered on the tape include the petrol engine, the carburettor, engine lubrication and the diesel engine.

results.title: How sugar is refined
results.brief_description: Describes how raw sugar is shipped to various refineries throughout Australia and also abroad. Shows the various stages in the manufacturing processes by which the raw product is converted into sugar fit for human consumption.
results.description: Describes how raw sugar is shipped to various refineries throughout Australia and also abroad. Shows the various stages in the manufacturing processes by which the raw product is converted into sugar fit for human consumption.

results.title: How raw sugar is made from cane
results.brief_description: Shows all stages in the manufacture of raw sugar from cane; initial crushing of the cane; extraction of raw sugar from the juice; the bagging and storage of the raw product and finally its transport for shipment. The film stresses the importance of the sugar industry in the economy of Australia.

results.title: How plants move
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “E.F.V.A. Primary Botany”.
Uses plants such as cress, beans, shamrocks and marrows to illustrate plant responses to light, gravity, water, day and night and touch. Time-lapse photography shows plant movements in detail. Gives a close-up examination of the trapping action of the venus fly-trap. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: How Not To Be Seen
results.brief_description: A satirical take on instructional films, How Not to Be Seen features a mix of actual and virtual performers and scenes, which illustrate the strategies for becoming invisible, communicated in an authoritative narrative voiceover. - MoMA

results.title: How many colours? = Cuantos colores?
results.creator_credit: Adam Sebire, Patrik Axen and AFTRS
results.brief_description: This short film asks us to consider the colours of Cuba: the variety of colours of the tobacco in their cigars; the multicultural array of colours of its people; the colours of socialism and the colours of the capitalists who are making it a tourist haven. Filmed largely in one of Havana’s biggest cigar producing factories, this film is also a celebration of a revolutionary culture where workers and working life has not become exclusively mechanised and rationalised. A vibrant celebration of Cuba, workers, unionism and the much maligned tobacco leaf.

results.title: How lightning shatters wood : the primeaval steam engine
results.brief_description: SUMMARY:Illustrates some of the effects of lightning. Shows alaboratory demonstration of lightning shattering wood. Lightning shatters trees with steam, this steam energy being converted into kinetic energy

results.title: How life begins
results.creator_credit: Gene Feldman, Daniel Wilson, American Broadcasting Company and Jules Power Productions
results.brief_description: Provides an understanding of the many and varied ways in which organisms, both simple and complex, reproduce. Introduces concepts of mitosis, courtship, nesting, fertilization and embryological development. Narrated by Eddie Albert.
